posts.cooked:
Hello,

I am using a Rev Through Bore Encoder on a practice control board (working on PID ). The Encoder was working just fine, outputting rotations. I continued working on other parts of code, and it stopped working. I reverted everything, and the encoder continued to not output values. I tried another encoder with another wire, and it too did not work.

I am using the DutyCycleEncoder class with .get(), and putting the number to shuffleboard. I also put isConnected and getFrequency on shuffleboard, which are true and 993 respectively. The encoder has stopped outputting values to shuffleboard, but the encoder appears to be connected, as the boolean value changes to false when I unplug the encoder, as well as the frequency dropping.

I am completely at a loss as to what could possibly be wrong here. Here is my code: GitHub - JChiu8/ControlBoard2025 (whoops I forgot to put it in team orginazation)

I sure hope I’m not accidentally frying each encoder I plug into. Thanks for the help.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Are you sure the problem is in your code, and not in shuffleboard? Have you tried another dashboard or OutlineViewer — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Natalie Daleo
posts.cooked:
Just wondering, but why are you using the DutyCycleEncoder class and ProfiledPIDController instead of rev’s closed loop system?

Also, have you checked if the encoder is being seen using rev hardware client?
We have not tried another dashboard, shuffleboard was working before though. I might try a different one to see if that works.

I am unfamiliar with REV’s closed loop system. We are currently wiring the encoder straight to the DIO ports on the RIO. Not sure how to check the encoder with the hardware client (unless I was using it as an alternate encoder, is that more effective?).

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
make sure its wired properly (according to rev’s docs: Application Examples | REV Crossover Products )

one key point - if your shaft does not have a magnet in it, the encoder will only return zeroes. if you wish to use the encoder in relative mode, you need to use wpi’s QuadratureEncoder class instead of DutyCycleEncoder

CalculusPenguin:

I am unfamiliar with REV’s closed loop system. We are currently wiring the encoder straight to the DIO ports on the RIO. Not sure how to check the encoder with the hardware client (unless I was using it as an alternate encoder, is that more effective?).

you can use the throughbore encoder with a sparkmax if you are not running a neo with it, to get direct PID feedback for rev closed loop control

It is wired properly. I am stumped because it was working before and now it isn’t.

Not sure what you mean about the shaft having a magnet, I had it working without a shaft (spinning it with my hands before we mounted it).

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Consider using an AMT-10 instead.  The REV thru-bore is not a very good encoder.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Yeah, in this case some of the solutions listed won’t work: You’re just treating it as any old generic encoder, so Rev tools won’t help.

I can confirm using a Duty Cycle Encoder will work in this use case, with basically the code listed, and it returns a value of 0 to 1 corresponding to the rotation. So, code looks pretty solid at a fundamental level. I believe you’re correct to have confidence that the code should work, so you should work to help diagnose how the hardware has gone wrong.

I think the key here is “worked before we mounted it”. So, if my programmers were stumped here, I’d start asking the following questions to troubleshoot.

Is it wired correctly to the Rio? In this case, that means correct wire was picked (since the rev breakouts have multiple plugs), and is it plugged into the correct rio port, and is it plugged into the correct way. For this system, that means the white wire, Digital Input 0, and with the white wire toward on the inside of the port, red in the middle, black toward the outside.

Is it correctly wired to the Through bore encoder? This should be easy, but worth checking.

Does it work correctly when moving the system it’s reading by hand? Periodic runs all the time, so this value does not need to enable the robot to see it. If the system moves, but the encoder doesn’t, that’s valuable information.

Does a different through bore encoder work when plugged into the same DIO port and code? If not, that’s probably a code error. If yes, then it’s likely that specific encoder and/or hardware.

Is the switch on the side of the encoder set to “A”? This is a sneaky error; If someone bumped it and switched it to S the encoder will do some unexpected things.

If the responses to this are “Yes,”, “yes”, “no”, “yes”, and “yes”, then you can conclude that the error is in either the encoder, or the mounting of the encoder. Maybe your team did something silly like use a round shaft or a small shaft which isn’t rotating the encoder properly as the system moves. Or attached it to a fixed shaft, rather than a rotating one. Or, maybe it was damaged during mounting, and needs to be replaced. Maybe they used a different wiring harness with an error, or made a custom one with an error (such as mixing up ground/power order, or got the wrong cable.

Thank you for your thoughtful response. I may have miscommunicated, but the encoder worked both before and after mounting, just stopped working after a code change, which once reverted, did not fix the issue.

Yes, the rio and encoder seem to be wired correctly.

No, the encoder does not return position values when the mechanism is moved by hand, but it does connect with a frequency.

No, a new encoder and wire did not correct the issue, as well as the first encoder being brand new.

I should definitely check the switch. Forgot about that, and it will be the first thing I try when the team meets next week.

Thank you, hopefully the switch is the issue.

Well, it wasn’t the switch, it was set to A.

The encoder works now though, so no more issue.

O future poor soul reading this with the same issue, I’m sorry. Not sure how it got fixed.
